text:
Not sure if anyone has CMO aspirations, but I read this and thought it was an insightful, brief read:
<https://www.forbes.com/sites/kimberlywhitler/2020/07/25/a-big-startup-mistake-hiring-the-wrong-head-of-marketing/#2cbe19cd4b81>

attachments.title: A Big Startup Mistake: Hiring The Wrong Head Of Marketing
attachments.text: To better understand why startup CMOs fail (and how not to fail), I turned to Matt Hirst, Partner at West, a venture studio that specializes in designing, building, and launching brands.
attachments.fallback: Forbes: A Big Startup Mistake: Hiring The Wrong Head Of Marketing

elements.text: Not sure if anyone has CMO aspirations, but I read this and thought it was an insightful, brief read:

text:
Hey <@ULKUFTFPW> literally the first client in my content marketing career was IBM. They created a branded publication on cloud technology and we had partnerships with Reuters to create engaging content on the industry.

The site isn't up any longer but Digiday gave IBM an award for Midsize Insider.  It was later renamed to Pivotpoint.

There definitely is plenty of demand for it. If you look at Forbes and SAP Brand Voice for example, and other native advertising campaigns, that's brand journalism in action.

I wouldn't say that companies just wake up and say "oh we should try brand journalism. It generally comes up during the content strategy development process.

For some companies and niches, it makes sense. For others it doesn't.
